titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Ed Wilkinson Collection ARS.0092
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Franz Kunst

publicationstmt.p: The Board of Trustees of Stanford University. All rights reserved.

profiledesc.descrules: Prepared using Describing Archives: a Content Standard

did.head: Descriptive Summary
did.abstract: The Ed Wilkinson Collection consists of classical and opera performance broadcasts of the 1930s and 40s on open reel tape, the majority of which from the Standard Symphony Hour series.

accessrestrict.head: Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for research; material must be requested at least two business days in advance of intended use. Contact the Archive for assistance.

userestrict.head: Publication Rights
userestrict.p: Property rights reside with repository. Publication and reproduction rights reside with the creators or their heirs. To obtain permission to publish or reproduce, please contact the Head Librarian of the Archive of Recorded Sound.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Ed Wilkinson Collection, ARS-0092. Courtesy of the Stanford Archive of Recorded Sound, Stanford University Libraries, Stanford, Calif.

acqinfo.head: Source
acqinfo.p: The Ed Wilkinson Collection was donated to the Stanford Archive of Recorded Sound by Ed Wilkinson in 1983.

processinfo.head: Sponsor
processinfo.p: This finding aid was produced with generous financial support from the National Historical Publications and Records Commission.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Ed Wilkinson Collection consists of seventy-two audiotape copies of radio programs of classical music and opera from 1934 to 1953. The collection, which was transferred by Wilkinson to tape in 1983, features the Standard Symphony Hour series (also known as the Standard Hour), the Metropolitan Opera, and the San Francisco Symphony and Opera. Various sources were used to assemble the programs. Each tape box has extensive technical and content notes.

Collector Ed Wilkinson was associated with the Western Sound Archive, a nonprofit archive founded by Nate Brown in Los Osos, California. Both Brown and Wilkinson share a long association with the Archive of Recorded Sound, and have donated many rare recordings. At one point, the Western Sound Archive was considered the source of nearly all circulating Standard Hour broadcasts. These Standard Hour programs comprise the majority of the Wilkinson collection. Many were dubbed from original network transcription discs once owned by Adrian Michaelis, program manager for the series. Other sources for the program are noted as NBC linechecks, Photo And Sound airchecks, and from other tapes. The Archive also holds many of the original NBC discs for Standard Hour in its transcription collection.

Orchestras include the Standard Symphony Orchestra, Los Angeles Philharmonic, and San Francisco Symphony Orchestra. Vocal soloists include Lotte Lehmann, Blanche Thebom, Lily Pons, Maggie Teyte, Dusolina Giannini, Jussi Bjoerling, and Bidu Sayao. Among the instrumental soloists are Joseph Szigeti, Robert Casadesus, Isaac Stern, and Artur Schnabel. The collection also contains some unusual performances by Yehudi Menuhin, such as a Stage Door Canteen broadcast from 1943 and a Town Hall concert with Wanda Landowska from 1944.

did.unittitle: Donizetti. L'Elisir d'amore. Antonicelli, Metropolitan Opera

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes intermission programs. NBC San Francisco linechecks, from collection of Adrian Michaelis. Transferred 1983.

did.unittitle: Gounod. Romeo and Juliet. Metropolitan Opera

scopecontent.head: Scope And Contents
scopecontent.p: Symphony conducted by Vladimir Golschmann. Florence Quartararo, soprano. From Standard Hour linechecks and AFRS discs from ARS Collection.

did.unittitle: Massenet. Manon. Wilfred Pelletier, Metropolitan Opera

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: From NBC lacquers, dubbed 1960, redubbed 1983.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: includes Town Hall concert with Wanda Landowska Dec. 20, 1944 ; Stage Door Canteen March 3, 1943 ; interviews, etc.

did.unittitle: Puccini. Madame Butterfly. Gennaro Papi, San Francisco Opera

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Act III not recorded. From NBC audition in Girard/Farwig collection, dubbed by Wilkinson 1983.

did.unittitle: Rossini. Il Barbiere di Siviglia. Gennaro Pap, Metropolitan Opera

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: From NBC linecheck in Girard/Farwig collection, dubbed by Wilkinson 1983.

did.unittitle: Saint-Saens. Samson and Delilah. Abravanel, Metropolitan Opera 1936-12-26 (reel 4 also contains Act 3 of Lohengrin, 1934-03-24)

scopecontent.head: Scope aned Contents
scopecontent.p: From NBC linechecks, dubbed 1960, pitched, edited and redubbed by Wilkinson 1982.

did.unittitle: Strauss. Der Rosenkavalier. Reiner, Metropolitan Opera (1949)
Strauss. Der Rosenkavalier. Reiner, Metropolitan Opera (1951)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Act I on Reel 9, acts II and III on Reel 10. "Present tape is a compound of a tape dub (majority of music) and linechecks/acetates, collection of A. Michaelis (intermissions, announcements, and two brief segments in Act I). Sound is good."

did.unittitle: Wagner. Die Meistersinger. Reiner, Metropolitan Opera

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies note
altformavail.p: Acts I and II on Reel 8. Act III on Reel 9. "Present tape is a composite of fair-sounding dub of highlights and a poorish AM dub of the complete performance, edited 1980 by E. Wilkinson. This is the only dub currently in circulation (April 1983)."

did.unittitle: Wagner. Lohengrin. Bodansky, Metropolitan Opera, Melchior (Box 3 contains Acts 1 and 2, Box 4 contains Act 3)
Wagner. Die Walküre. McArthur, San Francisco Opera, Melchior, Flagstad (Portion of Act 2)
Wagner. Tristan und Isolde. McArthur, San Francisco Opera, Melchior, Flagstad (Portion of Act 1)
